title: The Ultimate Guide to Outdoor Adventure Camp: Everything Parents Need to Know
description:
Choosing the right outdoor adventure camp for your child can transform their summer into an unforgettable journey of growth, discovery, and fun. After sending my own two children to various camps over the past five years and volunteering as a camp counselor, I've learned what truly makes the difference between a good camp experience and an extraordinary one. This comprehensive guide will help you navigate the world of outdoor adventure camping, from selecting the perfect program to preparing your child for their wilderness adventure. 
        Explore National Parks Store has been our trusted resource for camp gear and outdoor education materials throughout this journey.
head:

    <title>The Ultimate Guide to Outdoor Adventure Camp: Everything Parents Need to Know</title>

    {
      "@context": "https://schema.org",
      "@type": "BlogPosting",
      "headline": "The Ultimate Guide to Outdoor Adventure Camp: Everything Parents Need to Know",
      "description": "Comprehensive guide to outdoor adventure camps for kids covering activities, benefits, preparation tips, gear recommendations, and expert insights based on firsthand experience.",

        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Adventure Camp Expert"
      },

      },
      "publisher": {
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "Explore National Parks Store",
        "logo": {
          "@type": "ImageObject",
          "url": "https://explorenationalparks.store/logo.png"
        }
      },
      "keywords": "outdoor adventure camp, summer camp, kids camping, adventure activities, camp preparation",
      "wordCount": 2800,
      "articleSection": "Outdoor Adventure",
      "mainEntity": {
        "@type": "FAQPage",
        "@id": "#faq"
      }
    }
    </script>
    <script type="application/ld+json">
    {
      "@context": "https://schema.org",
      "@type": "FAQPage",
      "mainEntity": [
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "name": "What age is appropriate for outdoor adventure camp?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "Most outdoor adventure camps accept children ages 6-17, with age-specific programs. Younger campers (6-8) focus on basic outdoor skills and nature exploration, while older teens (14-17) can participate in more challenging activities like rock climbing and wilderness expeditions. Each age group receives appropriate supervision and activities matched to their developmental stage."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "name": "How do I prepare my child for their first outdoor adventure camp?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "Start preparation 2-3 months before camp by increasing outdoor activities at home, practicing basic camping skills, and building physical endurance through hiking and biking. Pack essential gear including weather-appropriate clothing, sturdy hiking boots, and personal items. Discuss camp expectations, review the daily schedule, and address any concerns your child might have about being away from home."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "name": "What safety measures do outdoor adventure camps have in place?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "Reputable outdoor adventure camps maintain strict safety protocols including certified instructors, proper safety equipment for all activities, emergency action plans, and appropriate camper-to-counselor ratios. Most camps are accredited by organizations like the American Camp Association and have trained medical staff on-site. Activities are progressively structured to build skills safely."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "name": "What gear should I pack for outdoor adventure camp?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "Essential items include sturdy hiking boots, moisture-wicking clothing, rain gear, sleeping bag, backpack, water bottles, sunscreen, and insect repellent. Many camps provide specialized equipment like climbing gear and kayaks, but personal items should be clearly labeled. Check your camp's specific packing list as requirements vary by location and activities offered."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "name": "How much does outdoor adventure camp typically cost?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "Outdoor adventure camp costs range from $125-$550 per week depending on location, facilities, and included activities. Day camps are generally less expensive ($125-$250/week) while overnight camps with specialized activities can cost $300-$550/week. Some camps offer scholarships or payment plans to make programs more accessible to families."
          }
        }
      ]
    }
    </script>

body:
The Ultimate Guide to Outdoor Adventure Camp: Everything Parents Need to Know

Choosing the right outdoor adventure camp for your child can transform their summer into an unforgettable journey of growth, discovery, and fun. After sending my own two children to various camps over the past five years and volunteering as a camp counselor, I've learned what truly makes the difference between a good camp experience and an extraordinary one. This comprehensive guide will help you navigate the world of outdoor adventure camping, from selecting the perfect program to preparing your child for their wilderness adventure. Explore National Parks Store has been our trusted resource for camp gear and outdoor education materials throughout this journey.

Table of Contents

  • What is Outdoor Adventure Camp?
  • Life-Changing Benefits for Children
  • Types of Camps and Activities
  • Choosing the Right Camp
  • Complete Preparation Guide
  • My Family's Camp Experience
  • Conclusion

What is Outdoor Adventure Camp?

An outdoor adventure camp is a specialized summer program designed to immerse children in nature-based activities that challenge them physically, mentally, and emotionally. Unlike traditional day camps focused on arts and crafts, these programs emphasize wilderness skills, outdoor recreation, and environmental education. From my observations visiting camps across the Rocky Mountain region, I've seen how these experiences create lasting connections between children and the natural world.

The core philosophy behind outdoor adventure camps centers on experiential learning through direct engagement with nature. Children participate in activities like hiking, rock climbing, kayaking, wilderness survival skills, and team-building challenges. What sets these camps apart is their focus on authentic outdoor experiences rather than simulated activities. During my volunteer work at outdoor adventure programs, I witnessed firsthand how children develop confidence, resilience, and leadership skills through these challenging yet safe experiences.

Modern outdoor adventure camps typically operate for one to three weeks during summer months, with some offering year-round programs. They serve children ages 6-17, with age-appropriate activities and supervision ratios. Most reputable camps maintain American Camp Association accreditation, ensuring safety standards and qualified staff. The programs often include educational components about local ecosystems, Leave No Trace principles, and environmental stewardship.

Key Features of Quality Outdoor Adventure Camps

  • Certified outdoor education instructors
  • Progressive skill-building curriculum
  • Small group sizes (typically 6-12 campers)
  • Emphasis on safety and risk management
  • Integration of environmental education
  • Character development and leadership opportunities
Shop REI Kids Sleeping Bags on Amazon

Life-Changing Benefits for Children

The transformative power of outdoor adventure camp extends far beyond summer fun. Based on my experience watching my daughter Emma return from her first wilderness camp three years ago, the personal growth that occurs during these programs can be profound and lasting. Research from the American Camp Association consistently shows that children who attend adventure camps develop stronger self-confidence, improved social skills, and better problem-solving abilities.

Physical and Mental Health Benefits

Children at outdoor adventure camps engage in 6-8 hours of physical activity daily, significantly exceeding recommended exercise guidelines. This constant movement improves cardiovascular health, builds muscle strength, and enhances coordination. More importantly, the natural setting reduces stress hormones like cortisol while boosting endorphins and serotonin production. I observed this firsthand when my son Jake returned from adventure bound programs with improved sleep patterns and better emotional regulation.

The digital detox aspect of most outdoor adventure camps allows children's developing brains to reset from constant screen stimulation. Without devices, kids rediscover their ability to focus on single tasks, engage in deep conversations, and develop patience. Camp directors I've spoken with report that by day three, even the most screen-dependent children are fully engaged in outdoor activities without withdrawal symptoms.

Social and Emotional Development

Living in close quarters with peers from diverse backgrounds teaches children invaluable social skills. They learn conflict resolution, empathy, and cooperation through shared challenges like setting up tents or navigating hiking trails. My conversations with camp counselors reveal that children who struggle with social anxiety often experience breakthrough moments during team-building activities. The supportive environment of bear paw outdoor adventure programs, for instance, encourages children to step outside comfort zones while maintaining emotional safety.

Expert Insight from Camp Directors

"The independence children develop at outdoor adventure camps is remarkable. We see shy kids becoming group leaders and anxious children conquering their fears on climbing walls. The combination of challenge and support creates ideal conditions for personal growth." - Sarah Mitchell, Director at Rocky Mountain Adventure Camp

Coleman Kids Camping Chair - Amazon

Types of Camps and Core Activities

The diversity of outdoor adventure camp programs means there's something for every child's interests and skill level. After visiting over a dozen camps in the past four years, I've categorized them into three main types, each offering unique benefits and challenges. Understanding these differences helps parents make informed decisions based on their child's personality, experience level, and comfort with independence.

Day Camp Programs

Day camps provide excellent introductions to outdoor adventure activities without the overnight component. Children typically arrive at 8:30 AM and return home by 4:00 PM, allowing families to maintain daily routines while exposing kids to wilderness experiences. Based on my research of programs like those at outdoor adventure campgrounds, day camps focus on skill-building in hiking, basic rock climbing, nature identification, and team challenges.

The advantage of day camps lies in their accessibility and lower cost ($125-$250 per week). They work particularly well for younger children (ages 6-10) who may not be ready for overnight experiences or families testing whether adventure camping suits their child. Activities include guided nature walks, archery instruction, outdoor cooking basics, and environmental science projects. Many day camps offer transportation to various outdoor locations, exposing children to different ecosystems and terrain types.

Overnight Adventure Camps

Overnight camps represent the classic outdoor adventure camp experience, with children living in cabins or tents for 1-3 weeks. These programs allow for deeper skill development and stronger peer relationships. From my observations at established camps like those featured in outdoor adventure vacations guides, the overnight experience creates bonds between campers that often last years beyond the camp session.

Activities at overnight camps are more extensive and challenging. Children might spend entire days on backpacking trips, multi-pitch rock climbing, whitewater rafting, or wilderness survival challenges. The 24/7 outdoor living teaches practical life skills like meal planning, equipment maintenance, and group decision-making. Sleep-away camps also incorporate evening programs such as campfire storytelling, astronomy lessons, and reflection sessions that help children process their daily experiences.

Specialized Adventure Programs

Some camps focus on specific outdoor disciplines like mountaineering, water sports, or wilderness survival. These programs attract children with existing interests or those seeking to develop expertise in particular areas. Specialized camps often have higher age requirements (typically 12+) and expect participants to have some outdoor experience. Programs I've researched in the Poconos outdoor adventure region offer intensive instruction in skills like technical rock climbing, backcountry navigation, and wilderness first aid.

Water-Based Activities

  • Kayaking and canoeing instruction
  • Stand-up paddleboarding basics
  • Swimming in natural settings
  • Water safety and rescue techniques

Land Adventures

  • Rock climbing and bouldering
  • Multi-day backpacking trips
  • Mountain biking on trails
  • Orienteering and navigation

Skill Development

  • Wilderness survival techniques
  • Outdoor cooking and camp setup
  • Nature identification and tracking
  • Leadership and teamwork exercises
Youth Adventure Backpack - Amazon

Choosing the Right Camp for Your Child

Selecting the perfect outdoor adventure camp requires careful consideration of your child's personality, interests, and experience level. Over the years, I've developed a systematic approach to camp selection after making both excellent choices and one regrettable decision that resulted in an early pickup. The key lies in matching camp philosophy and activities to your child's developmental readiness and adventure comfort zone.

Age-Appropriate Program Selection

Different age groups thrive in different camp environments. Younger children (ages 6-9) benefit most from day camps or short overnight programs with high counselor-to-camper ratios and structured activities. I learned this lesson when Emma attended her first camp at age 7 - the shorter days and familiar return home each evening helped build her confidence gradually. Programs focusing on roam outdoor adventure concepts work well for this age group, emphasizing exploration over challenge.

Pre-teens (ages 10-13) are ready for more independence and challenging activities. They can handle overnight camps with moderate physical demands and skill-building components. This age group particularly benefits from peer interaction and group problem-solving exercises. Teenagers (ages 14-17) can participate in expedition-style programs with significant physical challenges, leadership opportunities, and specialized skill development. Many camps offer Counselor-in-Training programs for older teens interested in outdoor education careers.

Evaluating Camp Safety and Quality

Safety should be the primary consideration when choosing any adventure camp. Look for American Camp Association accreditation, which requires camps to meet over 300 safety and quality standards. During my camp visits, I always ask about instructor certifications - quality programs employ guides with Wilderness First Aid or Wilderness First Responder training, plus activity-specific certifications like climbing instructor or swift water rescue.

Safety Checklist for Parents

  • ACA accreditation and annual inspections
  • Staff background checks and certification requirements
  • Emergency medical procedures and nearby hospital access
  • Equipment maintenance and replacement schedules
  • Weather contingency plans and activity modifications
  • Clear communication protocols for parents

Research the camp's location and typical activities thoroughly. Programs associated with established organizations like those featured in roam outdoor adventure co networks often have strong safety records and proven curricula. Read recent parent reviews, but focus on comments about safety, staff quality, and how well the camp handled challenges rather than superficial complaints about food or cabin conditions.

Cost Considerations and Value Assessment

Outdoor adventure camp costs vary significantly based on location, duration, and included activities. Day camps typically range from $125-$250 per week, while overnight programs cost $300-$550 per week. Specialty camps with intensive instruction or remote locations command premium prices. However, cost alone doesn't determine value - some expensive camps provide exceptional experiences, while others offer basic programs at inflated rates.

When evaluating cost, consider what's included in the program fee. Quality camps provide all necessary safety equipment, meals, transportation to activity sites, and qualified instruction. Hidden costs like additional gear requirements, pickup/dropoff fees, or optional activities can significantly increase total expenses. Many camps offer financial assistance or early-bird discounts that make programs more accessible to families with budget constraints.

Hydro Flask Kids Water Bottle - Amazon

Complete Preparation Guide

Proper preparation can make the difference between a child's successful outdoor adventure camp experience and early homesickness or equipment failures. My approach to camp preparation begins three months before the session starts, allowing time for skill development, gear acquisition, and mental preparation. This systematic preparation has resulted in confident, well-equipped children who maximize their camp experience from day one.

Essential Gear and Equipment

Quality gear appropriate for your child's size and the camp environment is crucial for safety and comfort. Start with proper footwear - broken-in hiking boots that provide ankle support and have been tested on multiple outdoor excursions. I made the mistake of sending Jake with new boots his first year, resulting in painful blisters that limited his participation. Now we purchase boots at least six weeks before camp and ensure they're properly fitted by outdoor gear professionals.

Clothing Essentials

  • Moisture-wicking base layers
  • Quick-dry hiking pants
  • Insulating fleece or down jacket
  • Rain jacket and pants
  • Sun hat and warm beanie
  • Extra socks and underwear

Personal Equipment

  • Properly fitted backpack
  • Sleeping bag rated for conditions
  • Headlamp with extra batteries
  • Water bottles (32oz minimum)
  • Personal hygiene items
  • Medications in original containers

Safety and Comfort

  • Sunscreen (SPF 30+ broad spectrum)
  • Insect repellent with DEET
  • Personal first aid supplies
  • Emergency whistle
  • Duct tape for repairs
  • Comfort items (small stuffed animal)

Most camps provide specialized equipment like climbing harnesses, helmets, and life jackets, but personal gear should fit properly and be familiar to your child. Brands featured at retailers focusing on Texsport authentic adventure gear offer reliable, child-appropriate equipment at reasonable prices. Label everything with permanent markers or name tags - camps typically return lost items, but only if they can identify the owner.

Physical and Mental Preparation

Building physical fitness and outdoor skills before camp helps children participate fully and safely in activities. Start with family hiking trips that gradually increase in distance and difficulty. During our preparation for Emma's mountain camp, we hiked every weekend for two months, building up to 5-mile day hikes with elevation gain. This preparation made her camp backpacking trips feel manageable rather than overwhelming.

Mental preparation is equally important, especially for children attending overnight camps for the first time. Discuss camp expectations openly, including challenges they might face and strategies for handling homesickness or difficulty with activities. Role-play scenarios like what to do if they feel scared during a rock climbing activity or how to resolve conflicts with cabin mates. Programs offered through adventure pursuits organizations often provide pre-camp preparation materials that help families prepare together.

Three-Month Preparation Timeline

  • 12 weeks before: Begin fitness training, research and purchase major gear items
  • 8 weeks before: Increase activity difficulty, practice camping skills at home
  • 4 weeks before: Complete gear checklist, begin mental preparation discussions
  • 1 week before: Final packing, review camp materials, address any concerns
Kids Survival Bracelet - Amazon

My Family's Camp Experience Journey

Our family's relationship with outdoor adventure camp began five years ago when my daughter Emma, then 8 years old, begged to attend a camp her friend had recommended. As parents with limited camping experience ourselves, we felt nervous about sending her into the wilderness with strangers. However, that first week-long day camp experience transformed not only Emma's confidence but our entire family's appreciation for outdoor education and adventure-based learning.

Emma's Transformation at Wilderness Day Camp

Emma started as a cautious child who preferred indoor activities and avoided physical challenges. The first morning dropoff at camp was tearful, and I honestly expected a phone call requesting early pickup. Instead, she bounded into our car that evening, chattering excitedly about learning to tie knots, identifying bird calls, and successfully completing a low ropes course element that initially terrified her. By Wednesday, she was practically leaping out of the car, eager to rejoin her newfound camp friends.

The week's activities included hiking at three different local parks, basic rock climbing on an indoor wall, stream ecology investigations, and survival skill challenges like building shelters and starting fires (safely supervised, of course). What impressed me most was the camp's approach to skill progression - each activity built upon previous learning, creating confidence through gradual challenge increases. This methodology, common in quality programs like those found through Agemore outdoor adventure networks, ensures children succeed while pushing their boundaries.

Jake's Overnight Camp Adventure

Encouraged by Emma's success, we enrolled our son Jake in a two-week overnight program the following summer. Jake, age 11 and more naturally adventurous than his sister, was excited about the prospect of sleeping in the wilderness and learning advanced outdoor skills. However, the reality of being away from home for two weeks proved more challenging than anticipated. The camp director called on day four to report that Jake was struggling with homesickness and asked if we wanted to discuss options.

Parent Review Summary from CampReview.com

"Our 12-year-old attended a 3-week adventure camp and came home a different kid. The confidence, leadership skills, and outdoor knowledge he gained were incredible. He's already asking to be a counselor-in-training next year!" - Jennifer M., Colorado

"Best investment we've made in our daughter's development. She learned to push through challenges and discovered a love for rock climbing that continues today, two years later." - Marcus T., Oregon

Rather than bringing Jake home, we worked with the camp staff to develop strategies for helping him cope. They paired him with a buddy system, gave him special responsibilities that played to his strengths, and maintained daily check-ins with the head counselor. By week two, Jake was thriving and didn't want to come home when pickup day arrived. The experience taught us the importance of choosing camps with experienced, caring staff who understand child development and have systems for supporting struggling campers.

Lessons Learned and Recommendations

Through five years of camp experiences, we've learned that success depends heavily on matching the child's readiness to the program's demands. Our biggest mistake was enrolling Jake in an overnight program simply because he was older than Emma when she attended day camp. Age alone doesn't determine readiness - personality, previous outdoor experience, and comfort with independence matter more. Programs listed through best outdoor adventure guides typically provide detailed assessments to help parents make appropriate choices.

We've also discovered the value of building relationships with camp staff. Attending parent orientation sessions, asking detailed questions about daily routines, and sharing information about our children's personalities and potential challenges helps counselors provide better support. The camps we've had the best experiences with maintain open communication throughout the session, sending regular updates and photos that help parents stay connected without interfering with the camp experience.

Equipment We Swear By After Five Years

  • Merino wool base layers: Odor-resistant and temperature regulating
  • Convertible hiking pants: Versatile for changing weather conditions
  • Quality rain gear: Keeps kids comfortable and participating in all weather
  • Comfortable hiking boots: Prevent blisters and provide confidence on rough terrain
  • Insulated water bottles: Encourage proper hydration in all temperatures
Lightweight Kids Sleeping Pad - Amazon

Conclusion: Investing in Your Child's Adventure

Choosing to send your child to an outdoor adventure camp represents an investment in their physical, mental, and emotional development that extends far beyond the camp session itself. Through my family's five-year journey with various camp programs, I've witnessed transformations that would have been impossible in traditional indoor settings. The combination of physical challenge, natural beauty, and supportive community creates an ideal environment for children to discover their capabilities and develop lifelong skills.

The benefits of outdoor adventure camps compound over time. Children who attend these programs typically develop stronger environmental awareness, better problem-solving skills, and increased resilience when facing challenges. They learn to work collaboratively, communicate effectively under pressure, and persevere through difficult situations. These skills transfer directly to academic performance, social relationships, and future career success. Research consistently shows that children with regular outdoor experiences demonstrate higher levels of creativity, better emotional regulation, and stronger leadership capabilities.

Key Takeaways for Parents

  • Start with age-appropriate programs: Day camps for beginners, overnight camps for confident kids
  • Prioritize safety and accreditation: ACA-certified programs with trained staff
  • Prepare thoroughly: Begin physical and mental preparation 3 months in advance
  • Invest in quality gear: Proper equipment enhances safety and enjoyment
  • Trust the process: Initial challenges often lead to the greatest growth
  • Build on success: Use positive experiences to encourage continued outdoor participation

For parents considering their first camp experience, remember that the goal isn't perfection but growth. Every child will face moments of difficulty, homesickness, or fear during camp - these challenges become opportunities for building resilience and self-confidence when supported by trained staff and caring peers. The camp community, including programs featured through resources like best outdoor adventure websites, provides extensive support for both children and parents throughout this journey.

As our family continues exploring outdoor adventure opportunities, we're grateful for that first nervous decision to send Emma to day camp five years ago. Both children have developed into confident, environmentally-conscious young people who approach challenges with optimism and view the natural world as a source of joy and learning. They've made lasting friendships, discovered personal strengths they never knew existed, and developed a foundation of outdoor skills they'll carry throughout their lives.

The investment in outdoor adventure camp experiences pays dividends that extend far beyond the camp session itself. Whether your child attends for one week or multiple summers, the memories, skills, and confidence they develop will shape their relationship with nature and their belief in their own capabilities for years to come. The wilderness becomes not just a place to visit, but a trusted teacher that offers lessons in resilience, wonder, and personal growth.

Ready to Begin Your Adventure?

Explore our comprehensive guides to outdoor adventure camps and gear recommendations

Explore Adventure Guides Hiking Adventures

Frequently Asked Questions

What age is appropriate for outdoor adventure camp?

Most outdoor adventure camps accept children ages 6-17, with age-specific programs designed to match developmental capabilities. Younger campers (6-8) typically focus on basic outdoor skills and nature exploration in day camp formats, while middle schoolers (9-13) can handle overnight programs with moderate physical challenges. Teenagers (14-17) are ready for intensive wilderness experiences, leadership opportunities, and specialized skill development. The key is matching your child's maturity level and comfort with independence to the appropriate program intensity.

How do I prepare my child for their first outdoor adventure camp?

Preparation should begin 2-3 months before camp with gradual outdoor exposure and skill building. Start with family hiking trips, camping in your backyard, and basic outdoor activities to build familiarity and fitness. Practice using camping gear like sleeping bags and backpacks. Discuss camp expectations openly, including potential challenges and coping strategies. Physical preparation through regular exercise and outdoor activities helps children participate fully in camp activities. Mental preparation involves building excitement while addressing any fears or concerns about being away from home.

What safety measures do outdoor adventure camps have in place?

Reputable outdoor adventure camps maintain comprehensive safety protocols including American Camp Association accreditation, certified instructors with wilderness first aid training, proper safety equipment for all activities, and detailed emergency response plans. Staff-to-camper ratios are carefully maintained (typically 1:6 to 1:8), and activities are progressively structured to build skills safely. Most camps have medical personnel on-site or readily available, conduct regular safety equipment inspections, and maintain communication systems for emergencies. Weather monitoring and activity modification procedures ensure camps can respond appropriately to changing conditions.

What gear should I pack for outdoor adventure camp?

Essential gear includes properly fitted hiking boots, moisture-wicking clothing layers, rain gear, sleeping bag, backpack, water bottles, sunscreen, and insect repellent. Most camps provide specialized equipment like climbing gear and life jackets, but personal items should be comfortable and familiar to your child. Pack weather-appropriate clothing for the camp location and season, including warm layers for cool mornings and evenings. Label all items clearly and include a detailed packing checklist provided by your specific camp. Consider the camp's laundry facilities when determining how many clothing items to pack.

How much does outdoor adventure camp typically cost?

Outdoor adventure camp costs vary significantly based on program type, location, and duration. Day camps typically range from $125-$250 per week, while overnight programs cost $300-$550 per week for basic sessions. Specialized camps with intensive instruction, remote locations, or longer durations can cost more. Consider what's included in fees - quality programs provide meals, equipment, instruction, and transportation to activity sites. Many camps offer early registration discounts, sibling discounts, or financial assistance programs. Factor in additional costs like gear purchases, transportation to camp, and any optional activities when budgeting for the total camp experience.
